This document provides an overview of the APIs available on the trainerdate.com servers, how to use
them, and the expected content structure.
Minor versions will be summarized into major versions upon major version changes.
Minor revisions related to removal of Elasticsearch, added pagination to GET library.
New notification when a friend creates a library entry.
Added object reference parameters to user_message.
Added object reference parameters to community_topic_message.
Added max_results to name_search and community_search.
Added pagination details to conversations retrieval API.
Added search querystring parameter to library search.
Added details on POST /notifications API (admin) to distribute notifications to users within a certain radius.
Added add_map querystring parameter for facility creation.
Amended subscription APIs to allow re-enabling a canceled subscription.
Added _ids input for user_master GET API.
Added after-the-fact receipt APIs for sponsored_event and subscription objects.
Added note that trainers can now book appointments for their clients by appending client_user_master_id to the querystring for POST /appointment.
Added facility_map object and clarity around facility
Change revision to 2.0.0 to account for multiple new features:
Added details about which events send notifications and of what type.
Added GET version of name_search and community_search.
Added details about notification and notification_pref objects.
Added community_master stats and community_topic stats.
Updated schedule object with facility details.
Updated schedule APIs with appropriate responses.
Added POST /appointment and amended POST /book (same API for now).
Updated name_search API to reflect JSON request body.
Added details around communities, topics, messages, and membership.
Updated to include profile picture in setup, friend API, sitemap.xml API
Updated to include the friend object and related APIs.
Updated to include changes to the booking API and appointments.
Updated to include address object and new res
clude conversations details API and latest_message object.
Updated to include user_profile objects and APIs.
Updated to reflect features and fixes for v1.2.0 of the backend API. Deprecated the user profile pic API. Added the generic BLOB store API.
Updated to reflect features and fixes for v1.1.0 of the backend API. The backend API includes the following new capabilities which should be exercised by front-end API consuming applications:
APIs for managing facility objects (specifying locations for events)
APIs for managing review objects (i.e. trainee leaving review for a trainer, responding to a review left for you as a trainer)
Class definition enhancements to provide more useful data in user_availability and user_message objects
APIs for generating and sending, as well as verifying, verification codes (via email and SMS)
APIs for creating and deleting multiple availability entries
APIs for adding, retrieving, and deleting user profile pictures
APIs for adding availability with daily or weekly recurrence
APIs for booking availability (sending email notifications and invites)
APIs for retrieving sorted/grouped user availability
These APIs were built to be backward-compatible with v1.0.0 API consumers.
This document provides an overview of the APIs available on the trainerdate.com servers, how to use them, and the expected content structure.
If ID is supplied in the URL, perform an update (object request body)
If no ID is supplied in the URL, perform a search (array of search filter request body)
POST  create an object, execute a logic API
Error messages will be of the following form:
id (int)  an internal identifier used to specify a class of error
http_status (int)  the HTTP status code returned, included in response object for simplicity
http_text (string)  the HTTP status description, included in response object for simplicity
file (string)  the file where the error was encountered
text (string)  a human-readable description of the error encountered
data (object)  an object, serialized, that may be useful to the caller
Note that text and data may be null. An example error response is shown below:
The following HTTP headers are supported and should be used as described:
Content-Type: should always be set to application/json
x-email: used to specify the email address of the user that should be authenticated to perform the API call
x-password: used to specify the password for the user that should be authenticated to perform the API call
x-token: temporal session key created from the login method that acts as a temporary replacement for the x-email and x-password credentials
x-api-key: used to specify an API key, currently only useful for the admin API key
x-latitude: used to specify the latitude reading from the devices geolocation sensor
. This value is often included in objects contained in the request body but also must be specified in the headers
x-longitude: used to specify the longitude reading from the devices geolocation sensor
This value is often included in objects contained in the request body but also must be specified in the headers

Admin APIs must be called using the admin API key. The admin API key must be set in the x-api-key header within the HTTP request. Even if the credentials supplied map to a user_master that is marked as an admin (i.e. user_master.is_admin == 1), the x-api-key header MUST be set with the admin API key, otherwise the request will be processed as a user API call.
NOTE: Admin APIs are not discussed in this documented as they are not required by client applications. This section will be expanded in the future.
The following APIs can be performed by any user without supplying authentication material.
Useful for verifying connectivity to the endpoint.

Useful when a user forgets their password. The server will send an email to the supplied email address containing a new password for the user account referenced by the email address in the request body.

This API should be called when onboarding a new user. If you wish to supply a list of service_id values with the request, you can call the API to retrieve services below (it is an unauthenticated call for this
The API takes a setup object in, and returns a user_master.
If you populate the profile_pic_url field, the profile picture will be retrieved and added to the profile.
This API will also create a user_profile object with template text and a valid Trainerdate profile URL.

This API is used to retrieve a verification code for either an email address or a phone number. Verification for email addresses are sent via email, and, verification for phone numbers are sent via SMS.
This API is used once the user has received their verification code. The API will return a 200/OK if the code is correct, or a 400/Bad Request (or anything other than 200/OK) if it is not.

Returns a token that can be used in the x-token header for subsequent authenticated requests. Alternatively, credentials can be supplied for every API call. Note: you may need to base64 encode the token string prior to using in the URL.

Returns a JSON dictionary containing the latitude and longitude for the address specified in the querystring address key-value pair. Be sure to URL encode the value that you place into the querystring. You can supply an address or simply a zip code.

Returns a JSON dictionary containing the approximate address associated with a set of supplied geocoordinates (latitude and longitude) as specified in the querystring latitude and longitude key-value pairs. Be sure to URL encode the value that you place into the querystring.
"formatted": "199 E Santa Clara St, San Jose, CA 95113, USA",

Returns a list of system_notification objects. These should be presented sequentially to the user as alert messages. No action should be taken by the application after displaying these notifications. If there are no system notifications, a 200/OK with either an empty response body or an empty array is returned.
This API allows you to send a test push notification. This API requires that the user_master object have its device_type and device_push_token specified.
The supported values for device_type are:
Only the ios value is implemented as of this writing.

Returns a list of version objects. If a version object is listed for the platform being used, the applications version should be compared against the minimum required version for that platform. If the application version is lower than the minimum required version, the app should direct the user to a page stating that a required update is available. The user should not be able to proceed from that page.

To generate a sitemap for the marketing website, including all user profiles, use this API. This API returns an XML file formatted to the standard sitemap.xml format, with all marketing pages and all profile pages.

The following APIs can be performed by any active, non-expired, authenticated user (i.e. by supplying either x-email/x-password or x-token, either in the URL querystring or as custom headers in the HTTP request).
Verifies that you can access authenticated APIs.
Note: you may need to base64 encode the token string prior to using in the URL.
/authenticated (set x-email and x-password, or, x-token), or
Returns the user_master object associated with the token supplied. This is useful for populating client devices with
the current user_master object which will supply metadata that may be required for subsequent requests.
This API should be called when updating user details for the current user.
only the fields that require updating
. Metadata including active, expiration, guid, created, and last_update do not need to be supplied.
This example shows four fields being updated. You can add any field from the user_master object that you wish to update (except is_admin, created, last_update, guid, active, and expiration).
Pull information about a user. This will likely be expanded in the future to include a more complete profile.
ill always return a list object even if there is only one item in the list.
If the list contains user records for other users, certain pieces of information (password, phone, etc) will be redacted.
NOTE: you can filter further if so desired
by adding fields to the querystring. You can also include coordinate information by using latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, and longitude_max
You can also select multiple IDs at once by including _ids=a,b,c where a,b,c is a list of user_master_id values.
user_master?_ids=a,b,c (for a series based on user_master_id)
This API allows you to store profile information about a user. Note you can only have one user_profile object per user_master_id.

This API allows you to updated stored profile information about a user. Note you can only update a user_profile object that has already been created. You can include any field from the original object aside for ID values, active, GUID, and timestamps.

This API allows you to delete stored profile information about a user. Note you can only delete a user_profile object that has already been created. Delete calls are processed by ID and can only be done by the user_master_id referenced in the user_profile object. No request body should be submitted.

GET or PUT calls can be used to retrieve user profiles. Using GET /user_profile?key=val& &key=val allows you to retrieve profiles where key/value pair combinations match exactly. GET /user_profile/n (n = user_profile_id) will return a specific user_profile. PUT with a search filter array body allows for more complex retrievals with conditions including equals, not equal, contains, contains not, starts with, and ends with.

When viewing a user profile, it is beneficial to record a profile view by using POST /profile_view. The user_master_id specified in the request body is the ID of the user whose profile was viewed. The viewers ID and other data will automatically be added to the object.
error if attempting to record viewing your own profile.
Profile views for the current user can be retrieved by calling GET /profile_view.

When viewing a user and it is determined that the user being viewed is not a premium user, it may be helpful to also show a list of recommended premium users. To search for recommended premium users, call GET /user_master/recommended and supply geocoordinate min/max values and a service_id list in the querystring
. The server will then search for trainers that are within those geocoordinate boundaries that focus on one of the specified service IDs.
Get List of User Master IDs in Conversations

Retrieve a list of integers representing user_master_id values associated with users with which the current user has an open conversation (i.e. active, unexpired user_message objects exist between the two users).

You can further filter the list by including the since parameter in the querystring, with a value set to a timestamp of the form MMddyyyyHHmmss. Be sure that you send values for since as UTC timestamps, as server objects are stored with UTC timestamps.
This API can be used as an alternative to GET /conversations in that it also returns the to and from user_master_id values, the timestamp of the last message, and the last messages content.

You can filter the list by including the since parameter in the querystring, with a value set to a timestamp of the form MMddyyyyHHmmss. Be sure that you send values for since as UTC timestamps, as server objects are stored with UTC timestamps.
Use this API to retrieve all messages sent or received by and between the current user and the specified peer user (by user_master_id).

You can also further filter for messages created after a certain time by appending the since parameter to the querystring with a value of the form MMddyyyyHHmmss. Be sure that you send values for since as UTC timestamps, as server objects are stored with UTC timestamps.

If you wish to retrieve paginated results, include index_start and max_results in the querystring. For example, to retrieve the first 20 messages, use ?index_start=0&max_results=20. To retrieve the next 20 messages, use ?index_start=20&max_results=20.
Use this API to retrieve all messages sent or received by a user. You can retrieve a specific message by appending the id to the URL.
Use this API to send a message from the currently-authenticated user to the specific recipient.
NOTE: If you wish to link to other objects in the message, set the following fields:
ref_obj_type  the type of object to which you wish to link
ref_obj_id_field  the object ID field name
ref_obj_id  the ID of the linked object
For instance, when linking to a library entry, use library_entry, library_entry_id, and 155 to link to library_entry_id 155.
Hey this is a message to you!

Use this call to either delete a specific message by including the ID in the URL, or, delete an entire conversation by not including a ID in the URL but rather including a JSON request body containing the user_master_id of the peer
(this can also be accomplished by adding user_master_id=n to the querystring, along with conversation=true)
Note: user_message objects are not actually deleted, rather, they are marked inactive and not returned when messages are later retrieve
Use this API to add a friend by user_master_id. Note that this creates a one-way relationship, and in order for the other person to consider you a friend, they must also call this API.
Use this API to retrieve a list of friends you have added and a list of friends that have added you.

Use this API to delete the one-way friend object between you (user_master_id_1) and another user (user_master_id_2). This does not delete any existing friend object between you and the other user in the reverse direction.
Use this API to search for user by name. Supply a
containing a key-value pair with key name search
. The server will create a search query that finds any matches in first_name and last_name (matches that start with, contain, or ends with).
Include max_results in the querystring to limit the number of results returned.
Additionally, you can use GET /name_search?search=<terms> to perform the same task. Add each search term to the search key in the querystring, and URL encode the terms.
This API is also available as an unauthenticated API (to assist during the onboarding process). The API will always return a list object, even if you request one object by ID.
Retrieve List of Trainers by Service

This API will retrieve a list of user_master objects that have service_map objects referencing the supplied service_id in the URL. You can geofence the request by setting latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, and longitude_max in the querystring.
Service maps create a map between a user_master that is a trainer and a service. Use this API to retrieve all
s associated with a user_master, all service_maps associated with a service_id.
This API will always return a list object containing service_map entries, even if there is only one service_map.
Use this API to create a service_map associated with a user_master
where the user_master is set up as a trainer
Use this API to delete a service_map associated with a user_master.

This API can be used to add availability for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1). A service_map object must be created first to specify that the trainer provides a certain service.
The parameter facility_id can be included in the request body to specify that the availability is offered at a pre-configured location.
This API will always return a list object, since recurrence can be specified.
To specify that event recurrence, add recur_type and recur_count to the querystring if you wish to have the entry repeat as follows:
recur_count: integer, must be 7 or less for daily, and 12 or less for weekly

This API can be used to add availability for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1) for multiple services for the same time slot. Rather than supply an integer for service_id, supply a string containing a comma-separated list of service_id values. The parameter facility_id can be included in the request body to specify that the availability is offered at a pre-configured location. With this API, one user_availability entry will be created
for each service_id specified. This API will always return a list object.
To specify that event recurrence, add recur_type and recur_count to the querystring if you wish to have the entry repeat as follows:
recur_count: integer, must be 7 or less for daily, and 12 or less for weekly
This API can be used to delete availability for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1).
Delete All Availability at a Specific Timeslot

This API can be used to delete all availability that matches the specified start_time and end_time of the supplied availability_id (from the URL). This API cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1.
In this example, if user_availability_id 2 had a start_time of 8/21/2015 08:00:00AM and an end_time of 8/21/2015 09:00:00AM, this API call would delete user_availability_id 2
user_availability object mapped to this user that has the same start_time and end_time.

Use this API to see what user_availability objects exist for a specific service, trainer, or within a given geography (or any combination therein). Filter by service by appending service_id to the querystring. You can further filter by adding user_master_id=n to the querystring. You can geofence the request by setting latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, and longitude_max in the querystring. You can specify the time parameters by including start_after and end_before parameters. You can specify a price range by including price_min and price_max parameters.
Alternatively, a PUT search can be used as shown. The same can also be accomplished using a PUT search to /user_availability with an array of search filters as the request body.
NOTE: Retrieval of user_availability objects may include default filters applied by the server:
GET /user_availability/n (n = user_availability_id) will NOT apply any filters beyond the ID value unless specified in the querystring
GET /user_availability (with or without querystring) will apply the following filters in addition to any supplied in the querystring:
PUT /user_availability (search) will NOT apply any filters other than those specified in the request body
Rather than simply retrieving a list of all availability matching specific criteria, append group_by to the querystring with one of the following values, each listed with its result:

user_master_id  results will be grouped by user_master_id into sub-objects inside an array. The object containing each sorted group will include the user_master_id for each user_availability object in the group
service_id  results will be grouped by service_id into sub-objects inside an array. The object containing each sorted group will include the service_id for each user_availability object in the group

coordinates  results will be grouped by latitude and longitude (rounded to 5 decimal places) into sub-objects inside an array. The object containing each sorted group will include the rounded latitude and longitude for each user_availability object in the group
NOTE: this function can ONLY be used with GET.
full user_availability object truncated for brevity

Use this API to send an email message containing a calendar invitation to both the client and the trainer. This API cannot be used by the user_master that created the user_availability_id included in the URL.

Schedule objects can be used as an alternative to using user_availability. While user_availability provides a higher degree of granularity (each object as an explicit timestamp and datestamp), schedule objects are simplified in that they are a generalization of a users schedule. For example, instead of using a user_availability object which says Im available at 3pm on 5/25/2016 at this location, a user can say Im available Wednesdays at 3pm at this location. Thus, the user will not have to continually add new user_availability objects.
You can add a schedule entry by submitting a JSON schedule object to POST /schedule.
To delete a schedule entry, call DELETE /schedule/n where n is the schedule_id.
A schedule entry can be updated by calling PUT /schedule/n where n is the schedule_id. This is commonly used to update price, time, day of week, or notes.
When calling GET /schedule, use the querystring filter ?user_master_id=n to only retrieve results for a specific user. It is not recommended that GET /schedule be called without this filter.
Search for Available Trainers by Schedule
Searching for trainers that may be available based on their schedule information can be accomplished by calling GET /schedules with the following querystring parameters (required fields are noted):
Note: 24-hour format, use 2-digits for hours always, i.e. 9am = 0900, 9pm = 2100
an have either user_master_id or coordinates as its value. The resul
If not specified, an array of schedule objects is returned
This API can be used to book an appointment with a trainer
. Specify the user_availability_id in the URL. Ensure that the caller user_master_id is not the same as the user_master_id in the user_availability object.
No response object is provided, however, email notifications are sent to both the trainer and client.
Further, the original user_availability object will have the client_user_master_id field updated (with the user_master_id of the requestor) and active will be set to 0.
This API can be used to book an appointment with a trainer based on a schedule

in the URL. Ensure that the caller user_master_id is not the same as the user_master_id in the user_availability object. No response object is provided, however, email notifications are sent to both the trainer and client.
or start_time and end_time, use the 24-hour format MMddyyyy-HHmm. Always use two digits for month, day, minute, and hour
. All times should be in UTC
Trainers can book appointments for their clients by adding client_user_master_id=n to the querystring
If you wish to schedule multiple appointments recurring either at daily or weekly intervals, add the following to the querystring:
This will create 10 instances from the start date, each separated by one day, recurring for 10 days total (including the first day)
The return object will be an array of appointments
This will create 5 instances from the start date, each separated by seven days, recurring for 5 weeks total (including the first day)
The return object will be an array of appointments

This API can be used to retrieve a list of all appointments with which the current user_master_id is associated (as a trainer or as a client). The list can be filtered by appending the appointment_id to the URL.
This API can be used to change elements in an appointment object.
Include the fields to change, along with the appointment_id, inside the request body.
NOTE: Updating an appointment does NOT notify the trainer or client via email.
This API can be used by trainers to delete an appointment. Specify the appointment_id in the URL. The trainer and the client will both be notified by email of the change.
NOTE: The original user_availability object will not be re-created upon deletion of the appointment. This is to allow the trainer to choose whether or not to have it re-created.
Facilities represent physical locations where services are rendered. A user can be linked to a facility by using a facility_map object (described in the next section).
Important Notes about Facilities and Maps

Facility map objects represent the link between a user and a facility. Thus, there are some points of coupling within the APIs for facility objects and facility_map objects that you should be aware of.
Creation of a facility  by creating a facility using POST /facility:
A facility_map object will also be created for that user
If the request contains data that is duplicate with a pre-existing facility, the facility_map object will link to the pre-existing facility by ID
If the request contains data that is not duplicate, a new facility object will be created, and the facility_map object will link to it accordingly
Deletion of a facility  by deleting a facility using DELETE /facility:
Any corresponding facility_map object for that user and facility will be deleted
If no other facility_map objects exist for that facilty_id, the facility will be deleted
Deletion of a facility_map  by deleting a facility_map using DELETE /facility_map:
The referenced facility_map object will be deleted
If no other facility_ap objects exist for the specified facility_id, the facility object will also be deleted
This API can be used to create a facility object for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where
is_trainer != 1). The facility object can then be linked to when

NOTE: Creating a facility will automatically create a facility_map object linking the requesting user to the specified facility. If you wish to NOT add the facility_map, append ?add_map=false to the querystring.
This API can be used to retrieve facility objects
Retrieve an individual facility by including the facility_id in the URL. Leaving the facility_id out of the URL will return all facility objects for that user.
Specify geo-boundaries in the querystring (latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, longitude_max) to retrieve all facility objects within a given geography.

This API can be used to update a facility object for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1). Specify the facility_id in the URL. Include only the fields in the request body that need to be modified. Fields that are not supplied will not be modified.
This API can be used to delete a facility object for a trainer (cannot be used by user_master where is_trainer != 1). Specify the facility_id in the URL.
Facility map objects are used to map users to facility objects, which indicates that the facility is a location where that user teaches or trains.
To create a facility map object, call POST /facility_map with the facility_id in the request body. The facility must already exist.
To delete a facility map object, call DELETE /facility_map/n where n is the facility_map_id.

To create a facility map object, call POST /facility_map with the facility_id in the request body. The facility must already exist. Note: due to the potentially large amount of data this call can return, it is recommended that you include facility_id or user_master_id in the querystring.

This API can be used to create a review for a user_master for a specific service_id and user_availability_id. The recipient user_master MUST have is_trainer == 1. Duplicate reviews for the same recipient user_master, service_id, and user_availability object will be declined.

This API can be used to by either party involved in a review object. The originator can use this API to update the comments or num_stars fields, and the recipient can use this API to update the response field. Both examples are shown.
really isnt as good as I thought
This guy really isnt as good as I thought
"comments": "This guy really isnt as good as I thought",
This API can be used to delete a review object by the user that created the review. Specify the review_id in the URL.
This API can be used to retrieve reviews written by the current user.
Get Reviews for a Trainer and/or Service
This API can be used to retrieve an object containing summary and detailed review information and statistics for a trainer and/or service.

Communities allow users to communicate in smaller groups. Communities are similar to forums or bulletin boards in that users can join as members, create topics, and then post messages to topics and reply to them. Communities use the following objects with the following purposes:

community_master  this is the top-level object for the community. All community-related objects will link back to a specific community_master. An example of a community_master would be Members of My Gym
community_member  this object defines the relationship between a user_master and a community_master. It indicates that a user is a member of the community and whether or not the user is active
community_topic  a topic is a conversation containing several messages, for instance, What are your plans for Thanksgiving? with a series of replies constitutes a topic

community_topic_message  a message is a discrete message contained within a topic. When a topic is created, the first message is created with it, and any subsequent replies will be linked to the community_topic (and of course the community_master)

ubmit community_master details in a JSON object to create a community. At a minimum, name, city, state, and country must be supplied. If you do not supply is_public, the community will be marked as private.
When you create a community_master object, the server will automatically create a community_member object for you, and return both in a dictionary.

To update a community, call PUT /community_master/n (n = community_master_id) with the fields you wish to change. This operation can only be completed by a user that is either the owner or admin of the specified community.
Search for a community by supplying a search filter array as the request body in a call to PUT /community_master.
Similar to the name search API provided for finding friends, the PUT /community_search API allows you to specify a series of search terms inside a JSON object (specifically, the search key).
Include max_results in the querystring to limit the number of results returned.
Additionally, you can use GET /community_search?search=<terms> to perform the same task. Add each search term to the search key in the querystring, and URL encode the terms.

Deleting a community actually does not delete, but rather, marks all associated community_* records as inactive. This is accomplished by calling DELETE /community_master/n where n is the community_master_id.
This can only be performed by a community admin.
To retrieve a list of all communities, call GET /community_master. You can filter by adding various parameters to the querystring, including latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, and
longitude_max. You can retrieve an individual community_master by using GET /community_master/n where n is the community_master_id.
Note: this API will always return an array object, even if requesting a single object by ID.

Append ?include_stats=true to the call GET /community_master to include detailed statistics for each community_master. Note that this will create several database queries (one per community_master) and thus should only be used on a small collection of communities.
(the entire community_master object is included here)

To join a community, call POST /community_member and specify community_master_id and user_master_id in the JSON request body. If the user_master_id does not align with the requestors user_master_id, the request will be treated as an invitation. Invitations can only be sent by community admins.
Users that have received community invitations can accept them by calling PUT /community_member/n where n is the community_member_id, and specifying a value of 1 for accepted.

Deleting a community invitation or leaving a community use the same API. To perform either of these functions, call DELETE /community_member/n where n is the community_member_id. A community admin can delete any community_member object within their community. A non-admin user can only delete their own community_member object.
Note: if an admin wishes to delete their own community_member object, they must first assign a new admin for the community, or, delete the community_master altogether.
Change Admin Status for Community Member
The admin status of a community_member can be changed by using PUT /community_member/n where n is the community_member_id.

To retrieve a list of all of your own community_member objects, call GET /community_member. This will return only community_member objects associated with your user_master_id. You can also specify a specific community_member_id by adding it to the end of the UR
L, i.e. GET /community_member/n (an array object will still be returned).
If you wish to see the members of a particular community, call GET /community_member
?community_master_id=n. Note that you must be a member of the specified community to retrieve its member list.

To create a community topic (i.e. a subject upon which messages can be created and linked to the topic), call POST /community_topic with the following fields in a JSON object in the request body: community_master_id, title, and message. Note that you must be
a member of the community to submit a community topic. A community_topic_message will be created from this request as well.
"message": "Welcome to TrainerDate! We're glad to have you."
"message": "Welcome to TrainerDate! We're glad to have you.",

To update or close a community topic, use PUT /community_topic/n where n is the community_topic_id. Specify either title, closed, or both in the request body. Note that this can only be done by an admin of the community.

To retrieve a list of community topics, call GET /community_topic?community_master_id=n where n is the community_master_id. To retrieve an individual community_topic, call GET /community_topic/n where n is the community_topic_id. In both cases, an array object will be returned.
Append ?include_stats=true to the call GET /community_topic?community_master_id=n to retrieve additional statistics about the community topic.
To search for community topics, use
PUT /community_topic with a search filter array request body. Note that community_master_id MUST be supplied as a search filter, otherwise the request will fail. This API will always return an array.

Community admins can delete community topics by calling DELETE /community_topic/n where n is the community_topic_id. Note that this does not actually delete the community_topic or the underlying community_topic_message objects, but rather marks them as inactive.
Post a Message to a Community Topic

Any community member can post a message to a community topic by calling POST /community_topic_message and specifying the following keys in a JSON object in the request body: community_master_id, community_topic_id, message. The user must be a member of the community_master and the community_topic must already exist
NOTE: If you wish to link to other objects in the message, set the following fields:
ref_obj_type  the type of object to which you wish to link
ref_obj_id_field  the object ID field name
ref_obj_id  the ID of the linked object
For instance, when linking to a library entry, use library_entry, library_entry_id, and 155 to link to library_entry_id 155.
A community admin or the author of a community_topic_message has the ability to modify a message by calling PUT /community_topic_message/n where n = the community_topic_message_id.
"message": "Well hi back at you! I hope you have a great day!"
"message": "Well hi back at you! I hope you have a great day!",

To retrieve the messages associated with a topic, an admin or member of the community can call GET /community_topic_message?community_topic_id=n where n is the community_topic_id. If you call GET /community_topic_message without this parameter, it will return the messages sent by the user. In both cases, an array is returned.
"message": "Well hi back at you! I hope you have a great day!",
Admins can delete messages by using DELETE /community_topic_message/n where n is the community_topic_message_id. These objects are not actually deleted, rather, they are marked inactive.

Trainerdate will send notifications for a variety of events through a variety of channels (SMS, email, push, and in-app). Users can control which notifications they receive by manipulating their list of notification_pref objects. In-

app notifications that are successful are stored as notification objects in the database  and other notification types (SMS, email, push) may be stored there in the future as well for a period of time (but are not currently).
By default, notifications are permitted unless otherwise denied by the presence of a notification_pref object.
The following table lists the events that, when encountered, trigger a notification, the notifications type, and whether or not it can be enabled or disabled.
(can only be disabled for push/app, not email)
New library document added by friend
New (user or trainer) in your area
users. They can only be created by the server, or, by administrative intervention.
To create a notification by administrative intervention

using an admin API key. Use the querystring to specify the center latitude and longitude, along with the number of miles to use as a radius to find matching users. To broadcast to all users, set miles to 0.
NOTE: as an admin API, none of the fields are managed
and must be provided as input (do not include notification_id
"notification_text": "New event nearby in San Jose: Luiz Panza Seminar!",

Notifications can be retrieved for the current user by calling GET /notification. This request can be filtered by including newer_than (timestamp as MMddyyyy-HHmmss) and read (Boolean) as querystring parameters. Further, any table field can be included in the querystring. Additionally, you can add an ID value to the URL to retrieve a specific notification.
You have a new friend on Trainerdate!

Notifications can and should be updated after they are read. This can be accomplished by calling PUT /notification/n (n = notification_id) with the appropriate fields to change. Generally, it is recommended that read_time and expiration be set. All timestamps should be supplied in UTC.
Like any other database object, expired notifications will be garbage collected by the server.

Notifications can be searched by calling PUT /notification (no ID in the URL) and supply an array of search_filter objects as the request body. Note that the user_master_id will automatically be included as a search filter.
Notifications can also be deleted by calling DELETE /notification/n (n = notification_id).

Notification preferences can be retrieved for the current user by calling GET /notification_pref. This request can be filtered by including any table field in the querystring. Additionally, you can add an ID value to the URL to retrieve a specific notification.
Notification preferences can be created for the current user by calling POST /notification_pref and supplying, at a minimum, the notification_type and enabled_* fields.

NOTE: Multiple overlapping notification_pref objects can exist, and when checking notification preferences, the first record retrieved will be used. Therefore it is important that the client manage and cleanup unneeded notification_pref objects.
Notification preferences can be deleted by calling DELETE /notification_pref/n (n = notification_pref_id).
Notification preferences can be updated by calling PUT /notification_pref/n (n = notification_pref_id) and including the relevant fields to update.

Notification preferences can be searched by calling PUT /notification_pref (no ID in the URL) and supply an array of search_filter objects as the request body. Note that the user_master_id will automatically be included as a search filter.
Payment card APIs are used to manage payment devices (credit cards) for use with subscriptions and other purchased products and services.
Payment card objects can be called by using POST /payment_card and supplying the card details in the request body. Required fields include pan, expire_mo, expire_yr,
, city, state, postal, country, and name_on_card.
Payment card objects cannot be updated. New payment card objects can be added instead.
Payment cards can be retrieved by calling GET /payment_card. Note that PAN and other sensitive information is never transmitted to the requestor; these values will be encrypted.
A payment cards can be deleted by calling DELETE /payment_card/n where n is the payment_card_id.

Transaction (txn) objects are objects that represent payment transactions that have been processed, typically in support of creation of or renewal of a subscription. These objects are managed by the server and can not be created or deleted by the requestor. The requestor can, however, retrieve or search transactions.
Retrieving transactions can be performed by calling GET /txn.
You can filter transactions by specifying search fields in the querystring (or the ID value in the URL).
Searching for transactions can be performed by calling GET /txn with a series of querystring filters, or, by using PUT /txn with a search filter array request body.
Subscription objects are objects that indicate products or services purchased by the user that are billed once or on a periodic basis, for instance, premium accounts.
To create a subscription, call POST /subscription with the following elements present:
subscription_type, and payment_card_id. The rest of the fields will be populated by the server according to the inputs.

When calling this API, the server will attempt to perform a charge against the linked payment card and create the necessary objects in support of the subscription. The response will include the subscription object and the txn object.

A subscription can be canceled by calling DELETE /subscription/n where n is the subscription_id. Note that this does not actually delete the subscription, rather, it marks it to no longer recur. Thus, the user will retain the full benefit of the subscription until the end_date is reached.
The next_recur value will be set to NULL and the recur_type will be set to none.
A subscription that has been canceled can be restarted by using PUT /subscription/n where n is the subscription_id and supplying new values for end_date, recur_type, and next_recur.

The only update that can be performed against a subscription is a change of payment_card_id. To update the payment_card_id associated with a subscription, call PUT /subscription/n (where n is the subscription_id) and pass a JSON object containing payment_card_id.
Generating a Receipt for a Subscription Payment

Receipts are automatically sent when a subscription is started or renewed. However, you can request an additional copy of a receipt by calling GET /receipt/subscription with the following items in the querystring:
email (optional, if not supplied, the users email address will be used)

Users can create sponsored events on the Trainerdate platform. Sponsored events are objects stored in the database that contain information about gatherings, meetups, any kind of event where there is an organizer, attendees, and a topic of interest.

, that is, the creator has to pay to list them. There is however a means by which events can be created without the user having to pay, if so desired by the application. For events that are paid, the user must have a payment card object stored in the server.

Sponsored events can be created by calling POST /sponsored_event. If you wish to charge the user for creating the event, include listing_fee=nn.nn in the request body to represent the amount. If you do not wish to charge the user, set listing_fee to 0 and add free_listing=true to the querystring. The following fields are required:

The API will return a JSON dictionary containing the sponsored_event object and the txn object associated with the payment. The txn object will still be present even for free_listing requests; the dollar amount will be zero.
est your strength all month long
Updating a sponsored event can be done by calling PUT /sponsored_event/n (n = sponsored_event_id). Many values are preserved and prevented from update, including various IDs.
Only supply the fields that require change.
"description": "Find a partner and create your own challenges!"
"description": "Find a partner and create your own challenges!",

To retrieve sponsored events, call GET /sponsored_event. To retrieve an individual sponsored_event, call GET /sponsored_event/n (n = sponsored_event_id). You can add an equals condition against any table field by including the field in the querystring, and you can add a geofence to the query by supplying latitude_min, latitude_max, longitude_min, and longitude_max.
To search for sponsored events, call GET /event_search and include ?search= with a series of URL-encoded space-separated search terms.
You can delete a sponsored event by calling DELETE /sponsored_event/n (n = sponsored_event_id). This will not actually delete the event, but rather, the event will be marked inactive.
Generating a Receipt for a Sponsored Event

Receipts are automatically sent when a sponsored event is listed. However, you can request an additional copy of a receipt by calling GET /receipt/sponsored_event with the following items in the querystring:
email (optional, if not supplied, the users email address will be used)

To register a user for a sponsored event, call POST /sponsored_event_attendee with a JSON request body containing the user_master_id and the sponsored_event_id. The API will return a sponsored_event_attendee object and send notifications to the organizer and the user.
Remove Registration for a Sponsored Event
To remove registration for a user from a sponsored event, call DELETE /sponsosred_event_attendee/n where n = the sponsored_event_attendee_id.

To retrieve sponsored event registration information, call GET /sponsored_event_attendee with either sponsored_event_id or user_master_id in the querystring. A list of sponsored_event_attendee objects is returned.

NOTE: you can add expand=true to the querystring to automatically expand objects referenced by ID such as sponsored_event_id, facility_id, and user_master_id. This is often helpful in reducing the number of subsequent API calls required after calling GET /sponsored_event_attendee.
Example with expansion (portions of the response simplified for brevity):
The Trainerdate server provides general BLOB (
ject) storage APIs for authenticated users. Some important notes about BLOBs:
BLOBs should be used to store things like image files and larger data structures that have no meaning to the backend
BLOBs can be accessed directly via their URL (available in the BLOB metadata)
BLOBs are accessible from any authenticated user
BLOBs, when created, are associated by user_master_id to the caller
BLOBs, when deleted, must be done by the same user_master_id
The following APIs are available for managing BLOBs:
Retrieval of metadata for one or multiple BLOBs (filterable)
BLOBs can be created by using POST /blob and appending the following items to the querystring:
blob_type  unmanaged by the backend, this is a classification supplied by the front-end which can also be used in BLOB retrieval as a filter, duplicates are allowed
name  unmanaged by the backend, this is a classification supplied by the front-end which can also be used in BLOB retrieval as a filter, duplicates are allowed
unmanaged by the backend, this is a classification supplied by the front-end which can also be used in BLOB retrieval as a filter, duplicates are allowed

Additionally, the content-type header must be set, as the BLOB data will be returned when requested with the specific content-type set. For instance, when storing HTML, it will be useful to set the content-type to text/html, whereas you may consider using image/png for a PNG image file.
IMPORTANT: you MUST URL encode your querystring.
Note that the response includes a URL field. This URL is directly accessible through the browser and can be embedded within web pages.
Metadata for BLOBs can be retrieved by using:
GET /blob?key=val (where key=val is a series of filters)
NOTE: returns an array of blob objects, even if only one is returned
NOTE: always returns a blob singleton
Metadata will never include the BLOB data. The data field will always be null.
Metadata for BLOBs can be updated by using PUT /blob/n (where n is the blob_id). Note that the ONLY fields that can be updated are:
If you wish to change the BLOB data or BLOB size, it must be deleted and then recreated.
The data associated with a BLOB can be retrieved by using GET /blob/n where n is the blob_id.
If the BLOB is an image, you can append the following to the querystring to cause the server to resize the image automatically: ?resize=true&width=n&height=n.
BLOB metadata is searchable using PUT /blob with a search filter array request body. Note that you can NOT search within BLOB data as it is not in the database.
BLOBs can only be deleted by the user_master_id that created them. This is done by using DELETE /blob/n where n is the blob_id.

The Trainerdate library is a content index that contains documents (external URLs or BLOBs) submitted by administrators or users. These documents can be public or private, and available to the general public or mapped to specific users. The documents can reference other objects (for instance, appointment by appointment_id) for purposes of association (as an example, notes shared by a trainer to a client for a particular appointment).

The APIs for the library provide an abstraction for a backend deployment of Elasticsearch v2.3, which is not exposed to the public Internet. These APIs serve as wrappers to limit the functionality and queries while providing a reasonable balance of usefulness.

Each library object is also stored in the Trainerdate database in the library_entry table. This table primarily exists to provide an autonomous repository from which the Elasticsearch index can be rebuilt if necessary. It could, however, also serve as a searchable table providing a similar function.
To add a document to the library index, call POST /library and supply a populated library_entry object.
The following values should be populated:
Set to the user_master_id of the recipient user. If there is no recipient user, set this to zero
Set to one if the document is public, otherwise set to zero
If the source document is not hosted in BLOB storage, set this value to one. Otherwise, set this value to zero
If the source document is not hosted in BLOB storage, set this value to the URL where the document can be retrieved
Set to one if the document is stored in the Trainerdate BLOB store
Set to the blob_id if the document is stored in the Tranierdate BLOB store, otherwise, set this value to zero
If this document should be associated with a specific object, specify the objects type here (for instance, appointment), otherwise set to null
If ref_obj_type is populated, set this to the name of the ID field used by this object type (for instance, appointment_id)
If ref_obj_type is populated, set this to the integer ID value for the specific object to which this document is associated (for instance, 3)
The URL that should be used when retrieving the image preview for this entry
Specify a title for the document (this field is searchable)
Supply a comma-separated string list of discrete tags for which this document should be searchable
Up to 2KB of data can be stored in the database and in the index for this document. This data is searchable. It is recommended that this field be used only when absolutely necessary (it shouldnt be)
data: 'just some data for the entry here, nothing really to see'
"data": "just some data for the entry here, nothing really to see",
If you wish to change the title, tags, or data of a document, you can use PUT /library/n (where n is the library_entry_id).
data: 'just some data for the entry here, nothing really to see'
"data": "just some data for the entry here, nothing really to see",

The server provides an API that allows a client to instruct the server to retrieve and parse the URL and provide a structured response containing data about the URL. This is useful when extracting terms, tokens, image URL
"keywords": "lift, lifting, weight, weights, cross, fit, crossfit, kettle, bell, kettlebell,
"description": "A short compilation of some cool stuff i did in 2012.",
"description_opengraph": "A short compilation of some cool stuff i did in 2012.",
To delete a specific document from the index call DELETE /library/n where n is the library_entry_id.
To search for documents stored in the
, call GET /library. A series of querystring parameters can be supplied that will help filter your results.
Each parameter added is ANDed with every other parameter, though some of the terms (for instance search, title, tags, data) may use OR internally.
Starting position within the results. This will default to zero if not supplied
The maximum number of results to retrieve. This can also be used in conjunction with index_start to implement pagination
Specify terms to search within document titles, tags, and data (all OR conditions)
Specify terms to search within document titles
Specify terms to search within document tags
Specify terms to search within document data
Specify the object type with which this document is associated
Specify the ID field of the object type with which this document is associated
Specify the ref_obj_id_field object ID value for the specific object of type ref_obj_type with which this document is associated
Specify the author user_master_id to search. Set to null if you wish to search for any author
Specify the recipient user_master_id with which to search. Set to zero if searching for general public documents
Specify whether to search for public documents (set to one) or private documents (set to zero)

It is important to note that permissions to library documents are NOT enforced within the API. That is, one user could potentially search for private documents for another user. This will be remedied in a future release with enhancements to the querybuilder.
"data": "just some data for the entry here, nothing really to see",
This API can be used to submit a request to support for issues, send feedback to support, or report an object (by type and identifier) as being inappropriate.
For support issues or feedback, leave flagged_object_type, flagged_object_id_field, flagged_object_id, and flag_reason null
To flag an item, set the flagged_object_type, flagged_object_id_field, flagged_object_id, and flag_reason, while adhereing to the following rules:
flagged_object_type should be of type user_master, user_message, or similar
flagged_object_id_field should be the type plus _id
flagged_object_id should be the ID of the object
flag_reason should be one of the following:
notes_from_user should be an open field, up to 512 characters in length
The following are the class definitions used by the application.
Contains information associated with user_availability objects that have been booked by a client.
Contains the address component associated with a set of coordinates.
Contains the metadata associated with a binary large object. The data is stored externally but accessible through the APIs described above.
public string data { get; set; } // do not persist
The community_master is the top level object for a community. All topics refer to the community_master by ID (community_master_id) as well as all community_member and community_topic_message objects.

The community_member object links a user_master_id to a community_master_id to indicate that the user is a member of the community. If the user is an admin in the community, set the is_admin value to 1.
The community_member object can also be used as an invitation: set the inviting users user_master_id in the invited_by_user_master_id field and set accepted to 0.

The community_topic object acts as a master object for all messages pertaining to a common subject (topic). The community_topic object is a subordinate to the community_master, and one or more community_topic_message objects may link back to the community_topic object.
The community_topic_message object holds an individual message associated with a community_topic. Each message or reply within a topic is stored as a discrete community_topic_message object.
Specifies a physical location, used by trainers and gym owners, to identify where a posted user_availability object will be taking place.
Specifies a linkage between a user and a physical location
Indicates a one-way relationship between two user_master objects. The user associated with user_master_id_1 has requested to be connected to the user associated with user_master_id_2.
Specifies a summary from user_message indicating a pair of user_master objects (by ID), number of messages, timestamp of the last message, and the last message content.
Specifies a document stored in the library and its source content.
Provides details for a notification that was sent to a user.
Indicates a users preference toward receiving a notification of a certain type. In the absence of a notification_pref record, it is assumed that the notification should be permitted.
Information about a user_masters credit card, stored in the database, generally for use with payment transactions supporting subscription billing
. Note: many of these fields are placeholders and are either A) not used by the application or B) not stored in the database (but are populated internally during processing).
Short-lived objects that indicate what user_master_id have viewed the profile of another user_master_id.
Feedback provided from a trainee to a trainer. Trainers can respond to reviews.
Object that summarizes a series of reviews associated with a user.
Specifies a specific day of week, time, location, and price where a trainer is available.

Specifies a filter to be used in a PUT search. field should contain a field from the object. condition should be one of a handful of supported database Boolean operators. value should be a string representation of the value being evaluated as part of the expression.
Specifies a type of training available to be offered by trainers.
Maps a trainer to a specific service, thereby specifying that the service is one offered by the trainer
Indicates a users interest in a specific service.

The object to use when creating an account on the system. For objects where is_trainer is set to 1, the service_id field indicates the services they provide. If is_trainer is set to 0, the service_id field indicates the services they are interested in.
This object contains metadata associated with an event listed by a user, i.e. a sponsored event.
This object is a map object that maps a user_master_id to a sponsored_event_id, i.e. specifies that a particular user is planning to attend a particular event.

An object containing details about a users subscription, mapping the details of the subscription to a particular user, specifying the billing frequency, and the method that should be used for payment.

Used to submit a support request, submit feedback, notify the system administrators of harassment, or notify the system administrators of data that is incorrect, inaccurate, or misrepresentation of fact.
Used to inform the user of upcoming events that may disrupt service or other situations that a user should be aware of.

Contains the details of a financial transaction, generally related to credit card transactions involved in subscription billing. Note: many of these fields are placeholders and are either A) not used by the application or B) not stored in the database (but are populated internally during processing).
Indicates when and where a trainer is available to teach a specific service.
The main object holding user data.

A message between users. Each message sent will be stored twice, once for the sender and once for the recipient. The user_master_id field will indicate who the owner of the database row is. This allows sender and recipient to each have their own copy to display locally and delete as desired.
Contains profile-related text and other information about a user. Linked to the user_master object by the user_master_id.
Represents the minimum application version required to interact with the backend. If the application version is less than the value found for the supplied platform, an application update is required.
